fall.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to move or drop down from a higher position to a lower position
fall.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The tree was about to fall.
The book fell from his hands.
Enough rain had fallen to flood the grounds.
She flushed and her eyes fell (=she looked down).
fall.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to suddenly go down onto the ground after you have been standing, walking, or running, especially without intending to
fall.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: I fell and hit my head.
Peter was playing by the river when he fell in (=fell into the water).
He slipped and fell on the ice.
She fell to her knees beside his body.
Lizzie fell down and hurt her knee.
fall.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to go down to a lower level, amount, price etc, especially a much lower one
fall.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The rate of inflation was falling.
The island is warm all year round and winter temperatures never fall below 10 degrees.
He believes that educational standards are falling.
London share prices fell sharply yesterday.
Advertising revenue fell from $98.5 million to $93.3 million.
The number of subscribers had fallen to 1,000.
fall.translation[0].definitions[2].note_: In everyday English, people often say an amount or level goes down rather than falls:
House prices have gone down again.
fall.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to start to be in a new or different state
fall.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I’ll stay with her until she falls asleep.
I think that I’ve fallen in love with Angela.
Albert fell silent and turned his attention to his food.
The house was empty for many years and fell into disrepair.
One false step can mean falling into debt.
fall.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to belong to or be part of a particular group, area of responsibility, range of things, or type of things
fall.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Many illnesses fall into the category of stress-related illnesses.
The judge said that this matter did not fall within the scope of the auditor’s duties.
The job falls under the heading of ‘sales and marketing’.
Meat production falls under the control of the Agriculture Department.
fall.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to start doing something or being involved with something, often without intending to
fall.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: I fell into conversation with some guys from New York.
He had fallen into the habit of having a coffee every time he passed the coffee machine.
fall.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: His dark hair fell over his face.
fall.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to shine on a surface or go onto a surface
fall.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The last rays of sunlight were falling on the fields.
Arthur’s shadow fell across the doorway.
fall.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to happen on a particular day or at a particular time
fall.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: I’d like to dedicate this record to all whose anniversaries fall at this time of year.
Her birthday will fall on a Friday this year.
fall.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if a leader or a government falls, they lose their position of power
fall.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: The previous government fell after only 6 months in office.
fall.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: if a place falls in a war or an election, a group of soldiers or a political party takes control of it
fall.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: The city fell to the advancing Russian armies.
fall.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to be killed in a war
fall.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to hit a particular place or a particular part of someone’s body
fall.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: The first punch fell on his nose.
fall.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: if someone’s voice or a sound falls, it becomes quieter or lower
fall.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to suddenly go down onto the floor when standing, walking, or running
She fell on the stairs and broke her ankle.
Children are always falling over.
trip on/over something
to fall or almost fall when you hit your foot against something
Someone might trip over those toys.
I tripped on a piece of wood.
slip
to fall or almost fall when you are walking on a wet or very smooth surface
She slipped and hurt her ankle.
I was scared I would slip on the highly polished floor.
stumble
to almost fall when you put your foot down in an awkward way
He stumbled and almost fell.
One of our porters stumbled on the rough ground.
collapse
to fall suddenly and heavily to the ground, especially when you become unconscious
One of the runners collapsed halfway through the race.
lose your balance
to become unsteady so that you start to fall over
She lost her balance on the first step and fell down the stairs.
Have something to hold onto, in case you lose your balance.
fall flat on your face
to fall forwards so you are lying on your front on the ground
She fell flat on her face getting out of the car.
fall.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: movement down towards the ground or towards a lower position
fall.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: the first fall of autumn leaves
The rise and fall of the dancers’ bodies creates a pattern.
Mrs Evans had a fall (=fell to the ground) and broke her leg.
He stretched out his hands to break his fall (=prevent himself from falling too quickly and hurting himself).
fall.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a reduction in the amount, level, price etc of something
fall.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: the sharp fall in the birth rate in European countries
There has been a fall in oil prices.
Their industrial output went down again in December, which meant a fall of 2.2% over the year.
fall.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: the season between summer and winter, when leaves change colour and the weather becomes slightly colder
fall.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Eleanor plans to go to Southwestern Community College this fall.
The area is beautiful in the fall.
fall.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a situation in which someone or something loses their position of power or becomes unsuccessful
fall.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: the story of Napoleon’s rise and fall (=period of success followed by failure)
Rumours are that the company is heading for a fall (=is likely to fail soon).
The president lived on for twenty years after his fall from power.
fall.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a situation in which a country, city etc is defeated by an enemy
fall.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: the fall of Jerusalem in AD70
fall.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: an act of forcing your opponent onto the ground in wrestling or judo
fall.translation[1].definitions[6].defin: an amount of snow, rocks etc that falls onto the ground
fall.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: The road is blocked by a rock fall.
Fresh falls of snow were forecast.
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with fall (meaning 3)
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].items[0]: You use in the fall or in fall when talking about something that happens during the fall season
He visited them in the fall
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].items[1]: You use in the fall of with a year when saying when something happens
The project will be completed in the fall of 2018
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].items[2]: Don’t use in with these words
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].items[3]: She started college in last fall
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].items[4]: This fall the leaves are really beautiful
In this fall the leaves are really beautiful
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].items[5]: The book will come out next fall
The book will come out in next fall
fall.translation[1].note_box[0].items[6]: That fall I went to Kyoto
In that fall I went to Kyoto
fall.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the story in the Bible that tells how Adam and Eve, the first man and the first woman, disobeyed God. According to the story, God forbids Adam and Eve from eating the fruit (sometimes called ‘the apple’) on the Tree of Knowledge in the Garden of Eden. The serpent (=snake) persuades Eve to taste the fruit, and then Eve gives the fruit to Adam to eat. They are ashamed of disobeying God and wear fig leaves because they are also now ashamed of having no clothes on. When they tell God that they have eaten the fruit he sends them out of the Garden of Eden. This story is supposed to describe the way that human beings first learnt about the difference between good and evil.
fall.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: to go down to a lower price, level, amount etc
fall.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Sales of new passenger cars in Europe fell 9.6%.
The British pound fell to $1.7520 from $1.7850.
The company went public at $17 a share, but its stock price has fallen sharply since then.
The consumer confidence index fell steeply (=by a large amount) from 79.3 in May to 50.9 in October.
fall.translation[3].definitions[1].defin: if a payment falls due on or by a particular date, it must be made on or by that date
fall.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: Subscriptions are payable annually and fall due on 1 December.
Of these sums, $44.2 million fell due for repayment within one year and a further $22 million fell due after more than one year.
fall.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: a reduction in the amount, level, price etc of something
fall.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: Japanese companies have tried to make up for a fall in domestic demand by increasing sales overseas.
There has been a sharp fall in the price of copper.
The steep fall in the Nikkei index means interest rates will stay low.
fall.translation[4].definitions[1].defin: when a person or organization loses their position of power or becomes unsuccessful
fall.translation[4].definitions[1].examp: the rise and fall of the British motorcycle industry
